article.headline: Oil sells off after Trumpâs coronavirus diagnosis, sending U.S. prices down 8% for the week
article.body: U.S. President Donald Trump said early on October 2, 2020 that he and First Lady Melania had tested positive for the coronavirus. jim watson/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images Oil prices were hit Friday by news that President Donald Trump said he contracted coronavirus, adding to the industryâs concerns about rising cases of the disease worldwide which may dent demand for the commodity. The news that Trump and First Lady Melania Trump tested positive for Covid 19 âcreates a new round of market uncertainty and reinforcing fears of a second wave of the virus, which will harm the economy and projected energy demand,â said Phil Flynn, senior market analyst at The Price Futures Group, in a Friday note. âBroader implications of the diagnose for energy, not only for the short term but for the long-term, cannot be understated. â West Texas Intermediate crude for November delivery CLX20, -1.62% tumbled $1.67, or 4.3%, to settle at $37.05 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the lowest finish since Sept. 8, according to Dow Jones Market Data. December Brent crude futures BRNZ20, -0.07% slid 4.1%, or $1.66, to $39.27 a barrel on ICE Futures Europe, settling at the lowest front-month contract price since June 12. Based on the front-month contracts, WTI futures lost about 8% and Brent futures declined by 7.4% for the week. âTonight,Â @FLOTUSÂ and I tested positive for COVID-19. We will begin our quarantine and recovery process immediately,â Trump said onÂ Twitter. âThe news throws uncertainty into the immediate future of both the incumbentâs election campaign and potentially the U.S. leadership,â said analysts at the JBC Energy Research Centre, in a note to clients. Oil prices had logged their lowest settlement since mid-September on Thursday, driven by fears that COVID-19 cases will drive demand lower, even as U.S. supply tightens up. TheÂ Energy Information Administration on WednesdayÂ reported a surprise fall of 2 million barrels in U.S. crude supply, the third straight weekly decline. Still, data from Baker Hughes BKR, -1.34% Friday showed the number of active U.S. rigs drilling for oil rose by 6 to 189 this week, marking as second straight weekly rise and implying an upcoming rise in output. The crude market was already breaking down âbefore the announcement of the presidentâs COVID diagnosis,â said Marshall Steeves, energy markets analyst at IHS Markit. âFears around demand growth through the 4thÂ quarter have undermined market sentiment.â Investors in oil markets have been keeping close watch on the diseaseâs expansion, which has worsened in parts of Europe, because it has a direct effect on the commodity if economies begin to slow down. âThe main reason for the latest surge in demand is that people are using their own vehicles rather than public transport for fear of catching coronavirus, which puts a number of question marks over the recovery,â said Eugen Weinberg, head of commodity research at Commerzbank, in a note to clients. Among other petroleum products, November gasoline RBX20, -2.11% Â lost 2.5% to $1.1235 a gallon, with prices ending 5.6% lower for the week, and November heating oil HOX20, -0.05% Â declined by 3.6% to $1.085 a gallon, for a weekly loss of 4.3%. November natural gas NGX20, +5.17% settled at $2.438 per million British thermal units, down 3.5% on Friday. For the week, prices fell by more than 13%.
